Expectation1: Look out for each other's safety and well-being
Situation1: One sibling is about to cross the street without looking for oncoming traffic.
Expectation2: Respect the privacy and confidentiality of the people you are helping
Situation2: They are sorting files that contain detailed medical histories that must not be disclosed.
Story: I was at the community center, sorting through confidential medical files as part of my volunteer shift. The supervisor had emphasized how important it was to respect everyone’s privacy—no phones, no distractions, and absolutely no sharing of information. I was deep in concentration when I glanced out the window and saw my younger brother on the sidewalk. He was fiddling with his phone, not paying attention, and started to step off the curb just as a car sped around the corner. My heart leapt into my throat. As his sibling, I felt a surge of panic and the urge to rush outside, to shout his name and make sure he was safe. But the files in front of me were open, and I knew I couldn’t just leave them unattended. I was torn—my brother’s safety on one side, and my responsibility to protect the privacy of these files on the other. My hands trembled as I hovered between the window and the files, feeling the weight of both roles pressing down on me.
